docs.title: Welcome to LaTeX for Beginners
docs.text: Welcome to the comprehensive guide for learning LaTeX, the de facto standard for scientific and academic publishing!

docs.title: What is LaTeX?
docs.text: LaTeX (pronounced "Lay-tech" or "Lah-tech") is a document preparation system for high-quality typesetting. It is most often used for medium-to-large technical or scientific documents but can be used for almost any form of publishing.

docs.title: Why Use LaTeX?
docs.text:
• Professional Typesetting: Creates beautiful documents with complex mathematical formulas.
  • Structured Documents: Encourages you to separate content from formatting.
  • Bibliographic Support: Automatic generation of bibliographies and citations.
  • Portability: LaTeX files are plain text files that can be edited on any computer.
  • Scalability: Capable of handling large documents (books, theses) with ease.

docs.title: How to use this Guide
docs.text:
This guide is structured to take you from a complete beginner to a confident LaTeX user.

  1. Getting Started: Install the necessary software.
  2. Basics: understand the structure of a LaTeX document.
  3. Mathematics: Learn how to write beautiful equations.
  4. Tables and Figures: Add data and images to your documents.
  5. Advanced: Master citations and custom commands.

Created with Material for MkDocs by Pulakesh Pradhan

docs.title: Bibliography and Citations
docs.text:
LaTeX makes referencing and formatting bibliographies powerful and automatic.

  1. BibTeX: The classic approach.
  2. BibLaTeX: The modern, feature-rich replacement.

docs.title: Creating a Database (.bib file)
docs.text:
Create a file like references.bib and add entries:

@article{einstein,
    author = "Albert Einstein",
    title = "{Zur Elektrodynamik bewegter K{\"o}rper}. ({German})
    [{On} the electrodynamics of moving bodies]",
    journal = "Annalen der Physik",
    volume = "322",
    number = "10",
    pages = "891--921",
    year = "1905",
    DOI = "http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/andp.19053221004"
}

@book{latexcompanion,
    author    = "Michel Goossens and Frank Mittelbach and Alexander Samarin",
    title     = "The \LaTeX\ Companion",
    year      = "1993",
    publisher = "Addison-Wesley",
    address   = "Reading, Massachusetts"
}

docs.title: In Your Document
docs.text:
Linking the .bib file:

\documentclass{article}

\begin{document}

Einstein's theory of relativity \cite{einstein} revolutionized physics.
The \LaTeX\ Companion \cite{latexcompanion} is an essential book.

\bibliographystyle{plain} % plain, unsrt, alpha, abbrv
\bibliography{references} % filename without .bib

\end{document}

docs.title: Compilation Order
docs.text:
1. pdflatex mydoc.tex (Creates .aux)
  2. bibtex mydoc (Creates .bbl)
  3. pdflatex mydoc.tex (Merges .bbl)
  4. pdflatex mydoc.tex (Updates references)

docs.title: 2. BibLaTeX (Recommended)
docs.text: BibLaTeX is easier to customize and handles complex citations better.

docs.title: Preamble setup
docs.text:
\usepackage[style=authoryear, backend=biber]{biblatex}
\addbibresource{references.bib}
  • style=ieee, apa, mla, authoryear, numeric.
  • backend=biber: Biber is the default engine for BibLaTeX (replace bibtex step with biber).

docs.title: Printing the Bibliography
docs.text:
Place \printbibliography where you want the references to appear.

\printbibliography[heading=bibintoc, title={References}]

docs.title: Natbib (Alternative)
docs.text:
Often used in sciences for author-year citations (\citep, \citet). Compatible with BibTeX styles.

\usepackage{natbib}
\bibliographystyle{plainnat}

docs.title: Custom Commands
docs.text: LaTeX allows you to define your own commands to simplify complex tasks or enforce consistency.

docs.title: Defining a New Command
docs.text:
Use \newcommand to create a new command. This is useful for abbreviations or commonly used phrases.

\newcommand{\R}{\mathbb{R}} % New command "R"
The real numbers are denoted by $\R$.

docs.title: Adding Arguments
docs.text:
You can create commands that take arguments. The number of arguments is specified in [] (up to 9). Use #1, #2, etc. to refer to them.

\newcommand{\boldtext}[1]{\textbf{#1}}

This is \boldtext{important}.

docs.title: Example: Complex Math Command
docs.text:
Instead of typing \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} repeatedly:

\newcommand{\pd}[2]{\frac{\partial #1}{\partial #2}}

The derivative is $\pd{f}{x}$.

docs.title: Optional Arguments
docs.text:
The first argument can be optional.

\newcommand{\plusbinomial}[3][2]{(#2 + #3)^#1}

Default (power 2): $\plusbinomial{x}{y}$ % (x+y)^2
Power 3:           $\plusbinomial[3]{x}{y}$ % (x+y)^3

docs.title: Renewing Commands (\renewcommand)
docs.text:
If a command already exists (like \emph or \section), use \renewcommand to change its definition.

\renewcommand{\abstractname}{Executive Summary}

docs.title: Defining Environments
docs.text:
Use \newenvironment{name}{begin code}{end code}.

\newenvironment{king}
    {\rule{1ex}{1ex}%
     \hspace{\stretch{1}}}
    {\hspace{\stretch{1}}%
     \rule{1ex}{1ex}}

docs.title: Embedding PDFs
docs.text: Sometimes you need to include pages from an existing PDF file into your LaTeX document. This is common for including certifications, full-page diagrams, or merging documents.

docs.title: The pdfpages Package
docs.text: The standard way to insert full PDF pages is using the pdfpages package.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
First, add \usepackage{pdfpages} to your preamble.

Then use the \includepdf command:

\documentclass{article}
\usepackage{pdfpages}

\begin{document}
  \includepdf[pages=-]{myfile.pdf} % Includes all pages
\end{document}

docs.title: Options for \includepdf
docs.text:
• pages={1}: Include only page 1.
  • pages={1,3}: Include pages 1 and 3.
  • pages={1-5}: Include pages 1 through 5.
  • pages=-: Include all pages.
  • scale=0.9: Scale the page down to 90%.
  • landscape=true: Rotate the included page.
  • pagecommand={\thispagestyle{plain}}: Keep page numbering on the included page.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
We have created an example file embedding-example.tex which embeds simple-report.pdf.

  • Source Code: embedding-example.tex
  • PDF to be embedded: simple-report.pdf
  • Resulting PDF: embedding-example.pdf

docs.title: Including PDFs as Images (graphicx)
docs.text:
If you just want to include a PDF file as a figure (like a chart generated by R or Python), treat it like an image.

\documentclass{article}
\usepackage{graphicx}

\begin{document}
  \begin{figure}[h]
    \centering
    \includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{chart.pdf}
    \caption{A chart from a PDF file}
  \end{figure}
\end{document}

LaTeX handles vector graphics in PDFs perfectly, maintaining high resolution.

docs.title: Document Structure
docs.text: Understanding how LaTeX structures documents is key to efficient writing.

docs.title: The Preamble
docs.text:
The preamble (before \begin{document}) defines everything about your document before the content starts:

  • Load \documentclass: The type of document you are creating (article, report, book, letter).
  • Load \usepackage: Any external packages you need (graphics, math, bibliography).
  • Set Up Metadata: Title, author, date (\title{...}, \author{...}, \date{...}).
  • Define Formatting: Font size (10pt, 11pt, 12pt), language ([english]), paper size ([a4paper]).

Example Preamble:

\documentclass[12pt, a4paper]{article}
\usepackage[utf8]{inputenc}
\usepackage{graphicx}
\usepackage{amsmath}

\title{My Research Paper}
\author{John Doe}
\date{\today}

docs.title: Classes
docs.text: Class Purpose Structure article Short documents without chapters (papers, reports, etc.) section, subsection, subsubsection report Longer documents with chapters (theses, technical documentation) chapter, section, subsection book Books (allows frontmatter, mainmatter, backmatter) part, chapter, sections... letter Letters opening, closing beamer Slides / Presentations frame, block

docs.title: Sections and Chapters
docs.text:
LaTeX automatically numbers headings and generates a Table of Contents.

  • \part{...} (only in Books)
  • \chapter{...} (only in Reports and Books)
  • \section{...}
  • \subsection{...}
  • \subsubsection{...}
  • \paragraph{...}
  • \subparagraph{...}

To create an unnumbered section (but still appear in the text), use the starred version (*): \section*{Introduction} (won't be numbered "1. Introduction").

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text: Place \tableofcontents where you want the TOC to appear. LaTeX generates it automatically based on your section commands. You may need to compile twice for the TOC to update correctly. To add unnumbered sections to the TOC, use \addcontentsline{toc}{section}{Introduction}.

docs.title: Bulleted Lists (itemize)
docs.text:
\begin{itemize}
    \item First item
    \item Second item
\end{itemize}

docs.title: Numbered Lists (enumerate)
docs.text:
\begin{enumerate}
    \item First item
    \item Second item
\end{enumerate}

docs.title: Description Lists (description)
docs.text:
\begin{description}
    \item[First] The first definition.
    \item[Second] The second definition.
\end{description}

docs.title: Lists
docs.text: Lists are fundamental for structuring content. LaTeX supports bulleted (itemize), numbered (enumerate), and description (description) lists.

docs.title: Bullet Points (itemize)
docs.text:
\begin{itemize}
    \item Apples
    \item Oranges
    \item Bananas
\end{itemize}

docs.title: Numbered List (enumerate)
docs.text:
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Introduction
    \item Methods
    \item Results
\end{enumerate}

docs.title: Descriptions (description)
docs.text:
\begin{description}
    \item[HTML] HyperText Markup Language
    \item[CSS] Cascading Style Sheets
\end{description}

docs.title: Nested Lists
docs.text:
You can nest lists up to 4 levels deep.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item Fruit
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Apple
        \item Banana
    \end{itemize}
    \item Vegetables
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Carrot
        \item Potato
    \end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

docs.title: Customizing Lists (The enumitem Package)
docs.text:
To customize list styles (e.g., replace bullets with dashes, change numbering to a), b)), use the enumitem package.

Add to preamble: \usepackage{enumitem}.

docs.title: Custom Bullets
docs.text:
\begin{itemize}[label=$\star$]
    \item Star item 1
    \item Star item 2
\end{itemize}

docs.title: Custom Numbering
docs.text:
• label=\alph* -> a, b, c
  • label=\Alph* -> A, B, C
  • label=\roman* -> i, ii, iii
  • label=\Roman* -> I, II, III
  • label=\arabic* -> 1, 2, 3
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
    \item First item (a)
    \item Second item (b)
\end{enumerate}

docs.title: Spacing
docs.text:
Remove vertical space between items using nosep or adjust itemsep.

\begin{itemize}[nosep]
    \item Compact Item 1
    \item Compact Item 2
\end{itemize}

docs.title: Text Formatting
docs.text: LaTeX provides robust commands for styling text.

docs.title: Font Styles
docs.text: Style Command Example Bold \textbf{text} This is \textbf{bold} text. Italic \textit{text} This is \textit{italic} text. Underline \underline{text} This is \underline{underlined} text. Typewriter \texttt{text} This is \texttt{monospaced} text. Small Caps \textsc{text} This is \textsc{small caps} text. Sans Serif \textsf{text} This is \textsf{sans serif} text. Roman (Default) \textrm{text} This is \textrm{serif} text.

docs.title: Combining Styles
docs.text: You can nest commands: \textbf{\textit{Bold and Italic}}.

docs.title: Font Sizes
docs.text:
LaTeX has built-in relative font size commands:

Command Size Default 10pt Default 11pt Default 12pt \tiny Tiny 5pt 6pt 6pt \scriptsize Script Size 7pt 8pt 8pt \footnotesize Footnote Size 8pt 9pt 10pt \small Small 9pt 10pt 11pt \normalsize Normal 10pt 11pt 12pt \large Large 12pt 12pt 14pt \Large Larger 14pt 14pt 17pt \LARGE Even Larger 17pt 17pt 20pt \huge Huge 20pt 20pt 25pt \Huge Huge 25pt 25pt 25pt

Example: {\Large This text is large.}

docs.title: Left Align (Default)
docs.text: \begin{flushleft} ... \end{flushleft}

docs.title: Right Align
docs.text: \begin{flushright} ... \end{flushright}

docs.title: Center Align
docs.text: \begin{center} ... \end{center}

docs.title: Quotes
docs.text:
Use the quote for single paragraphs and quotation for multiple paragraphs.

\begin{quote}
    This is a short quote.
\end{quote}

docs.title: Creating Space
docs.text:
• \hspace{1cm}: Horizontal space.
  • \vspace{1cm}: Vertical space.
  • \hfill: Fill remaining horizontal space (pushes text to the right).
  • \vfill: Fill remaining vertical space (pushes text to the bottom).
  • \newpage: Start a new page.

docs.title: How to Run These
docs.text:
1. Open the .tex file in your editor (e.g., VS Code or Overleaf).
  2. Compile the document using pdflatex or your editor's build button.
  3. Observe the generated PDF output.

docs.title: Choosing an Editor
docs.text: A specialized LaTeX editor makes writing code much easier with syntax highlighting, auto-completion, and integrated PDF viewing.

docs.title: 1. Visual Studio Code (Cross-Platform)
docs.text:
Highly Recommended

VS Code is a powerful, extensible code editor. When combined with the LaTeX Workshop extension, it provides a top-tier LaTeX experience.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Intellisense: Autocompletion (commands, labels, bibtex keys).
  • Structure View: Outline of sections/chapters for easy navigation.
  • SyncTeX: Click in PDF -> jump to code. Ctrl+Click in code -> jump to PDF.
  • Linting: Errors/warnings shown inline as you type (ChkTeX).
  • Snippets: Expand common patterns (e.g., fig -> complete figure environment).

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
1. Install VS Code.
  2. Open Extensions (Ctrl+Shift+X).
  3. Search for "LaTeX Workshop" (by James Yu).
  4. Install.

docs.title: 2. Overleaf (Online)
docs.text:
Best for Collaboration

Overleaf is a cloud-based LaTeX editor. It requires no installation and allows real-time collaboration (like Google Docs).

docs.title: Pros
docs.text:
• Zero Setup: Just sign up and start writing.
  • Collaboration: Multiple users can edit simultaneously.
  • Rich Text Mode: "Word-like" editing for beginners.
  • Templates: Thousands of templates (journals, CVs, theses).

docs.title: Cons
docs.text:
• Offline Access: Limited (requires paid plan/git sync).
  • Compile Time: Can be slow on free tier for large documents.

docs.title: 3. Dedicated Editors
docs.text: These specific applications are designed purely for LaTeX.

docs.title: TeXstudio (Windows/Mac/Linux)
docs.text:
A feature-rich IDE. It has many buttons and menus to insert symbols, making it very beginner-friendly if you don't know commands by heart.

  • Wizards: For tables, arrays, newly created documents.
  • Symbol Panel: 1000+ symbols accessible via click.

docs.title: TeXShop (macOS only)
docs.text: Simple, clean, and reliable. Comes with MacTeX. It focuses on the source and preview without clutter.

docs.title: TeXworks
docs.text: Minimalist editor often included with MiKTeX/TeX Live. Good for simple edits but lacks advanced features like structure view or strict autocompletion.

docs.title: Recommendation
docs.text:
• New to coding? Start with Overleaf.
  • Want a powerful local setup? Use VS Code + LaTeX Workshop.

docs.title: Your First LaTeX Document
docs.text: Let's create our first LaTeX file and understand the basic anatomy of a document.

docs.title: Creating a File
docs.text:
Create a new file called hello-world.tex (or use the example file 00_Creating_a_LaTeX_Document.tex from this guide).

Type the following code:

hello-world.tex
\documentclass[12pt]{article}
\usepackage{amsmath, amssymb, amsfonts}

\title{My First Document}
\author{Your Name}
\date{\today}

\begin{document}

\maketitle

Hello! This is my first \LaTeX\ document.

A rectangle has side lengths of $(x+1)$ and $(x+3)$.
The equation $A(x) = x^2+4x+3$ gives the area of the rectangle.

\end{document}

docs.title: Compilation
docs.text: To turn this into a PDF, you need to compile it. In VS Code with LaTeX Workshop, simply save the file (Ctrl+S). The output should look like a formatted document with the title, author (you), and today's date, followed by your text.

docs.title: Understanding the Structure
docs.text: Every LaTeX document has two main parts:

docs.title: 1. Preamble (Before \begin{document})
docs.text:
The preamble sets up the document.

  • \documentclass{article}: Defines the document type (article, report, book, letter). The [12pt] option sets the base font size.
  • \usepackage{...}: Loads external packages to add functionality (like amsmath for math support).
  • \title{...}, \author{...}: Metadata commands.

docs.title: 2. Body (\begin{mcdocument} ... \end{document})
docs.text:
The actual content of your document goes here. Everything outside this environment is ignored or part of the preamble.

  • \maketitle: Prints the title, author, and date.
  • $...$: Inline math mode.
  • \LaTeX: A command that prints the LaTeX logo.

docs.title: Common Errors
docs.text:
• Mismatched \begin{...} and \end{...}.
  • Forgetting \usepackage{...} for a command (e.g. using \frac without amsmath sometimes works but best practice is to load it).
  • Using special characters like %, $, &, _, {, }, # without escaping them (e.g. \%).

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Now you have a basic document structure. Let's learn how to format text in the next section.

docs.title: Getting Started with LaTeX
docs.text: Before we write our first document, we need to install a LaTeX distribution and an editor.

docs.title: Step 1: Install a LaTeX Distribution
docs.text: A LaTeX distribution provides all the tools and packages needed to process your LaTeX code and produce PDF documents.

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
• MiKTeX: A popular, lightweight distribution. It installs packages on-the-fly as you need them.
  • TeX Live: A comprehensive distribution (large download) covering everything.

Recommendation: Go with MiKTeX if you have limited space, or TeX Live for a complete setup.

docs.title: macOS
docs.text: • MacTeX: Based on TeX Live, this is the standard distribution for macOS. It includes TeXShop and other utilities.

docs.title: Linux
docs.text:
Most Linux distributions manage TeX Live through their package managers:

sudo apt-get install texlive-full  # Debian/Ubuntu (Note: lengthy install!)
sudo dnf install texlive-scheme-full # Fedora

docs.title: Online Alternative (No Installation)
docs.text: If you prefer not to install software, use Overleaf. It's a powerful online LaTeX editor with real-time collaboration and cloud storage. Perfect for beginners!

docs.title: Step 2: Choose an Editor
docs.text:
A specialized LaTeX editor makes writing code much easier with syntax highlighting and auto-completion.

  1. Visual Studio Code: The most popular code editor today. Install the LaTeX Workshop extension by James Yu. It is powerful and customizable.
  2. TeXShop (macOS only): Simple and effective, comes with MacTeX.
  3. TeXworks / TeXstudio: Dedicated LaTeX IDEs with many built-in features.

Recommendation: VS Code + LaTeX Workshop for a modern experience.

docs.title: Brackets
docs.text: Scale brackets automatically using \left and \right.

docs.title: Parentheses ( )
docs.text: $$ \left( \frac{1}{2} \right) $$ \left( ... \right)

docs.title: Square Brackets [ ]
docs.text: $$ \left[ \begin{matrix} 1 & 0 \ 0 & 1 \end{matrix} \right] $$ \left[ ... \right]

docs.title: Curly Braces { }
docs.text: $$ \left{ x \in \mathbb{R} \mid x > 0 \right} $$ \left\{ ... \right\} (Must escape \{!)

docs.title: Absolute Value | |
docs.text: $$ \left| -5 \right| = 5 $$ \left| ... \right|

docs.title: Angle Brackets < >
docs.text: $$ \langle u, v \rangle $$ \langle ... \rangle or \left\langle ... \right\rangle

docs.title: Matrices and Arrays
docs.text:
Requires amsmath. Standard environments:

  • matrix: No brackets.
  • pmatrix: Parentheses ( ).
  • bmatrix: Square brackets [ ].
  • Bmatrix: Curly braces { }.
  • vmatrix: Single bars | | (determinant).
  • Vmatrix: Double bars || || (norm).

The structure is similar to a table:

  • Rows are separated by \\.
  • Columns are separated by &.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
pmatrix: $$ \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} $$

\begin{pmatrix}
  1 & 2 \\
  3 & 4
\end{pmatrix}

bmatrix: $$ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \ 4 & 5 & 6 \ 7 & 8 & 9 \end{bmatrix} $$

\begin{bmatrix}
  1 & 2 & 3 \\
  4 & 5 & 6 \\
  7 & 8 & 9
\end{bmatrix}

docs.title: Creating Cases Functions
docs.text:
Use the cases environment for piecewise functions.

\[ f(x) = \begin{cases} 2x & x > 0 \\ 0 & x \le 0 \end{cases} \] 
f(x) = \begin{cases}
  2x & x > 0 \\
  0 & x \le 0
\end{cases}

docs.title: Common Mathematical Notation
docs.text: The amsmath, amssymb, and amsfonts packages are essential.

docs.title: Superscripts & Subscripts
docs.text:
• Superscripts: ^
  • \(x^2\) - x^2
  • \(e^{-x}\) - e^{-x} (Note: multiple characters must be in {})

  • \(2^{3x+1}\) - 2^{3x+1}

  • Subscripts: _

  • \(a_n\) - a_n
  • \(x_{i,j}\) - x_{i,j}

  • \(H_2O\) - H_2O

  • Combined

  • \(x_i^2\) - x_i^2

docs.title: Greek Letters
docs.text: Lowercase Command Uppercase Command \(\alpha\) \alpha \(A\) A \(\beta\) \beta \(B\) B \(\gamma\) \gamma \(\Gamma\) \Gamma \(\delta\) \delta \(\Delta\) \Delta \(\epsilon\) \epsilon \(E\) E \(\zeta\) \zeta \(Z\) Z \(\eta\) \eta \(H\) H \(\theta\) \theta \(\Theta\) \Theta \(\iota\) \iota \(I\) I \(\kappa\) \kappa \(K\) K \(\lambda\) \lambda \(\Lambda\) \Lambda \(\mu\) \mu \(M\) M \(\nu\) \nu \(N\) N \(\xi\) \xi \(\Xi\) \Xi \(\pi\) \pi \(\Pi\) \Pi \(\rho\) \rho \(P\) P \(\sigma\) \sigma \(\Sigma\) \Sigma \(\tau\) \tau \(T\) T \(\upsilon\) \upsilon \(\Upsilon\) \Upsilon \(\phi\) \phi \(\Phi\) \Phi \(\chi\) \chi \(X\) X \(\psi\) \psi \(\Psi\) \Psi \(\omega\) \omega \(\Omega\) \Omega

docs.title: Operators
docs.text:
• Summation: \sum_{i=1}^n \(\sum_{i=1}^n\)
  • Integral: \int_a^b \(\int_a^b\)
  • Limit: \lim_{x \to \infty} \(\lim_{x \to \infty}\)
  • Product: \prod \(\prod\)

docs.title: Brackets and Parentheses
docs.text:
Scale automatically with \left and \right.

  • \left( \frac{1}{2} \right) \(\rightarrow \left( \frac{1}{2} \right)\)
  • \left[ ... \right]
  • \left\{ ... \right\} (Use \{ for braces)
  • \left| ... \right| (Absolute value)
  • \left\langle ... \right\rangle (Angle brackets)

docs.title: Sets
docs.text:
• \(\in\) \in
  • \(\notin\) \notin
  • \(\subset\) \subset
  • \(\subseteq\) \subseteq
  • \(\cup\) \cup
  • \(\cap\) \cap
  • \(\emptyset\) \emptyset
  • \(\infty\) \infty
  • \(\mathbb{R}\) \mathbb{R} (Real numbers - amsfonts)
  • \(\mathbb{Z}\) \mathbb{Z} (Integers)
  • \(\mathbb{N}\) \mathbb{N} (Natural numbers)
  • \(\mathbb{C}\) \mathbb{C} (Complex numbers)

docs.title: Text in Math Mode
docs.text: Inside math mode, spaces are ignored. Use \text{...} to write normal text. text{if } x > 0 \(\rightarrow \text{if } x > 0\)

docs.title: Fractions
docs.text:
Use \frac{numerator}{denominator}.

  • \(\frac{1}{2}\) - \frac{1}{2}
  • \(\frac{a+b}{c+d}\) - \frac{a+b}{c+d}
  • Need larger fractions? Use \dfrac{...}{...} (display fraction).
  • Need inline fraction? Use \tfrac{...}{...} (inline fraction).

docs.title: Roots
docs.text:
Use \sqrt{...} for square roots and \sqrt[n]{...} for nth roots.

  • \(\sqrt{2}\) - \sqrt{2}
  • \(\sqrt[3]{8}\) - \sqrt[3]{8} (cube root)
  • \(\sqrt{x^2+y^2}\) - \sqrt{x^2+y^2}
  • \(\sqrt{1+\sqrt{x}}\) - \sqrt{1+\sqrt{x}}

docs.title: Complex Examples
docs.text: Combining these features: $$ x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a} $$ $$ x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a} $$

docs.title: Inline vs Display Math
docs.text: Math is LaTeX's super power. There are two primary modes for typesetting mathematics:

docs.title: 1. Inline Mode ($...$)
docs.text: Use inline mode to mix mathematical symbols within the flow of text. For example, writing $E=mc^2$ produces \(E=mc^2\) right here.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
• Wrap your math expression in single dollar signs: $ ... $
  • Alternatively, use \( ... \) (LaTeX standard).

Example: The equation for a line is \(y = mx + b\), where \(m\) is the slope and \(b\) is the y-intercept.

docs.title: 2. Display Mode (\[...\] or $$...$$)
docs.text: Display mode centers the equation on its own line and uses larger symbols for readability. For example: $$ \int_0^\infty e{-x2} dx = \frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2} $$

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
• Unnumbered Equation: Use \[ ... \] (recommended) or $$ ... $$ (TeX primitive, often used but less robust).
  • Numbered Equation: Use the equation environment for automatic numbering.

Example (Numbered):

\begin{equation}
    x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}
    \label{eq:quadratic}
\end{equation}

This will produce a centered equation with a number like (1) on the right side. You can reference it later using \ref{eq:quadratic}.

docs.title: Aligning Equations
docs.text:
For multi-line equations, use the align environment (requires amsmath package). alignment points are marked with &.

\begin{align}
    f(x) &= (x+1)^2 \\
         &= x^2 + 2x + 1
\end{align}

The \\ creates a new line. The & aligns the equals signs.

To suppress numbering for specific lines, use \nonumber or switch to align*.

docs.title: Figures and Images
docs.text:
To include images, you need the graphicx package: \usepackage{graphicx}.

Supported image formats:

  • JPEG (.jpg)
  • PNG (.png)
  • PDF (.pdf) - (Yes, PDFs can be images!)
  • EPS (.eps)

docs.title: Including an Image (\includegraphics)
docs.text:
The \includegraphics{filename} command inserts an image at the current location. Always specify its size or scaling.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\linewidth]{myimage.png}
  • width=0.5\linewidth: Sets the image width to 50% of the text width.
  • width=5cm: Sets the width to exactly 5 cm.
  • height=2in: Sets the height to exactly 2 inches.
  • scale=0.8: Scales the image to 80% of its original size.
  • angle=90: Rotates the image 90 degrees.

docs.title: Floating Figures (figure Environment)
docs.text:
Like tables, figures usually float. LaTeX decides where to place them to optimize page breaks.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
    \centering
    \includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{graph.png}
    \caption{A descriptive caption for the graph.}
    \label{fig:mygraph}
\end{figure}
  • \centering: Centers the figure horizontally.
  • [htbp]: Placement preference:
  • h: Here (at this precise location in the code).
  • t: Top of a page (default).
  • b: Bottom of a page.
  • p: Page of floats (all figures together).
  • !: Override internal parameters (force harder).
  • \caption: Adds "Figure 1: ..." text.
  • \label: Adds an internal reference (e.g., Reference Figure \ref{fig:mygraph}).

docs.title: Subfigures (subcaption)
docs.text:
To place multiple images side-by-side, use the subcaption package (\usepackage{subcaption}).

\begin{figure}
    \centering
    \begin{subfigure}[b]{0.45\textwidth}
        \includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{image1}
        \caption{Image A}
    \end{subfigure}
    \hfill
    \begin{subfigure}[b]{0.45\textwidth}
        \includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{image2}
        \caption{Image B}
    \end{subfigure}
    \caption{Two images side-by-side}
\end{figure}

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Image not found? Ensure the filename and path are correct. Use relative paths (images/logo.png) or absolute paths.
  • Image too big? Use width=\textwidth to constrain it to the page width.
  • Figure "floating away"? This is normal behavior. Use \clearpage to force all pending floats to place before continuing.

docs.title: Tables
docs.text: Tables in LaTeX can be tricky at first. The basic environment is tabular.

docs.title: Basic Table Structure
docs.text:
\begin{tabular}{c c c}
  A & B & C \\
  1 & 2 & 3 \\
  4 & 5 & 6 \\
\end{tabular}
  • {c c c}: Defines three columns, all centered.
  • l: Left-aligned column.
  • r: Right-aligned column.
  • c: Center-aligned column.

  • |: Vertical line separator (e.g., {l|c|r}).

  • &: Separates cells in a row.

  • \\: Ends a row.
  • \hline: Draws a horizontal line across the table.

docs.title: Example with Lines
docs.text:
\begin{tabular}{|l|c|r|}
  \hline
  \textbf{Item} & \textbf{Qty} & \textbf{Price} \\
  \hline
  Apples & 5 & \$1.00 \\
  Oranges & 10 & \$2.00 \\
  \hline
\end{tabular}

docs.title: Floating Tables (table Environment)
docs.text:
To make a table "float" (LaTeX decides the best position) and add a caption, wrap tabular in table.

\begin{table}[h]
    \centering
    \begin{tabular}{l c r}
        \hline
        Task & Duration & Status \\
        \hline
        Design & 2w & Done \\
        Code & 4w & In Progress \\
        Test & 2w & Pending \\
        \hline
    \end{tabular}
    \caption{Project Timeline}
    \label{tab:project}
\end{table}
  • [h]: Try to place the table here. (Options: here, top, bottom, page).
  • \centering: Centers the table.
  • \caption{...}: Adds a descriptive title.
  • \label{...}: Use this to reference the table (Table \ref{tab:project}).

docs.title: Professional Tables (booktabs)
docs.text:
For publication-quality tables, use the booktabs package (\usepackage{booktabs}). It provides better spacing and cleaner lines.

  • \toprule: Top line (thick).
  • \midrule: Middle line (thin).
  • \bottomrule: Bottom line (thick).
\begin{table}[ht]
    \centering
    \begin{tabular}{@{}llr@{}} \toprule
        \multicolumn{2}{c}{Item} \\ \cmidrule(r){1-2}
        Animal & Description & Price (\$)\\ \midrule
        Gnat  & per gram & 13.65 \\
        & each     & 0.01 \\
        Gnu   & stuffed  & 92.50 \\
        Emu   & stuffed  & 33.33 \\
        Armadillo & frozen & 8.99 \\ \bottomrule
    \end{tabular}
    \caption{A nice table with booktabs}
\end{table}
